metadata.subject: physics
metadata.dotPoint: compare alternating voltage expressed as the root-mean-square (RMS) to a constant DC voltage developing the same power in a resistive component

ac_voltage_variation.name: AC Voltage Variation
ac_voltage_variation.correct: AC voltage continuously varies between positive and negative peak values, following a sinusoidal pattern.

constant.fix: AC = alternating current. The voltage alternates between positive and negative values.
constant.action: Sketch one cycle of AC voltage. It should look like a sine wave crossing zero twice.

always positive.error: AC swings both positive and negative.
always positive.fix: The 'alternating' in AC means the polarity reverses each half-cycle.
always positive.action: Look at the Vp-p value. It spans from +Vp to -Vp.

randomly varying.fix: AC follows a smooth sinusoidal pattern with fixed frequency and amplitude.
randomly varying.action: The regularity of AC is what makes power calculations possible.

persistent.gap: You do not understand the fundamental nature of AC voltage.
persistent.action: Watch AC on an oscilloscope. Observe the smooth, repeating pattern.

peak_voltage_definition.name: Peak Voltage Definition
peak_voltage_definition.formula: Vp = maximum voltage in one cycle
peak_voltage_definition.correct: Peak voltage is the maximum absolute value reached by the AC voltage in one cycle.

average voltage.error: The average of AC over a full cycle is zero, not the peak.
average voltage.fix: Peak is the maximum value, not the average.
average voltage.action: On a V-t graph, peak is the highest point above zero (or lowest below zero).

peak-to-peak voltage.error: Vp-p is double the peak voltage.
peak-to-peak voltage.fix: Vp-p goes from +Vp to -Vp, so Vp-p = 2Vp.
peak-to-peak voltage.action: If Vp = 325 V, then Vp-p = 650 V.

RMS voltage.error: RMS is less than the peak voltage.
RMS voltage.fix: Vrms = Vp/√2, so Vrms is always smaller than Vp.
RMS voltage.action: Calculate: if Vp = 100 V, Vrms = 100/1.41 = 71 V.

persistent.gap: You are confusing different measures of AC voltage.
persistent.action: Draw a sine wave and mark: Vp (amplitude), Vp-p (total swing), Vrms (effective value).

peak_to_peak_voltage.name: Peak-to-Peak Voltage
peak_to_peak_voltage.correct: Peak-to-peak voltage is the total voltage swing from maximum positive to maximum negative, equal to twice the peak voltage.

Vp-p = Vp.fix: Peak-to-peak spans from +Vp to -Vp, a total of 2Vp.
Vp-p = Vp.action: If Vp = 10 V, the voltage swings from +10 V to -10 V, so Vp-p = 20 V.

Vp-p = Vp/2.error: Inverted. Vp-p is larger than Vp, not smaller.
Vp-p = Vp/2.action: On an oscilloscope, Vp-p is the full height of the wave.

Vp-p = Vrms.error: Vp-p is much larger than Vrms.
Vp-p = Vrms.action: For 230 V AC mains, Vp-p ≈ 650 V.

persistent.gap: You do not understand the relationship between Vp and Vp-p.
persistent.action: Measure Vp-p on an oscilloscope trace, then divide by 2 to get Vp.

rms_definition.name: RMS Definition
rms_definition.correct: RMS stands for Root-Mean-Square, a mathematical averaging method that gives the effective value of AC.

regular mean square.error: The order matters: Root of the Mean of the Squares.
regular mean square.fix: RMS = √(mean of V²). Square first, then average, then root.
regular mean square.action: Process: (1) square all values, (2) find mean, (3) take square root.

running mean sum.error: RMS stands for Root-Mean-Square, not running mean sum.
running mean sum.fix: The name describes the mathematical process: root of the mean of squares.
running mean sum.action: Remember: R-M-S = Root, Mean, Square (though the process is square, mean, root).

real measured signal.error: RMS is a mathematical concept, not a type of measurement.
real measured signal.fix: RMS is a calculation method that gives the effective value.
real measured signal.action: RMS can be calculated from any signal, measured or theoretical.

persistent.gap: You do not understand what RMS means mathematically.
persistent.action: Calculate RMS manually: square several values, average them, take square root.

rms_voltage_formula.name: RMS Voltage Formula
rms_voltage_formula.correct: For sinusoidal AC, the RMS voltage equals the peak voltage divided by √2 (approximately 1.414).

Vrms = Vp × √2.error: Inverted. RMS is smaller than peak, so divide, not multiply.
Vrms = Vp × √2.fix: Vrms = Vp/√2. Dividing makes Vrms less than Vp.
Vrms = Vp × √2.action: Check: Vrms should be about 71% of Vp, not 141%.

Vrms = 2Vp.error: That would give peak-to-peak, and in the wrong direction.
Vrms = 2Vp.fix: Vrms < Vp. RMS is always less than peak for sinusoidal signals.
Vrms = 2Vp.action: RMS = Vp × 0.707, which is less than Vp.

Vrms = Vp.error: RMS and peak are different values.
Vrms = Vp.fix: Vrms = Vp/√2 ≈ 0.707 × Vp. They are not equal.
Vrms = Vp.action: For 230 V RMS mains, Vp = 325 V. They differ by factor of √2.

persistent.gap: You have not memorised the RMS formula correctly.
persistent.action: Write Vrms = Vp/√2 ten times. Then calculate Vrms for several Vp values.

rms_current_formula.name: RMS Current Formula
rms_current_formula.correct: For sinusoidal AC, the RMS current equals the peak current divided by √2.

Irms = Ip × √2.error: Inverted. RMS is smaller than peak.
Irms = Ip × √2.fix: Irms = Ip/√2. Same relationship as voltage.
Irms = Ip × √2.action: RMS values are always less than peak values for AC.

Irms = Ip/2.action: Same formula structure as Vrms = Vp/√2.

Irms = Ip × 2.error: Multiplying gives a larger value. RMS must be smaller.
Irms = Ip × 2.fix: Irms = Ip/√2, which is about 0.707 × Ip.
Irms = Ip × 2.action: If Ip = 10 A, then Irms = 10/1.414 = 7.07 A.

persistent.gap: You do not recognise that current and voltage follow the same RMS relationship.
persistent.action: Both formulas are identical in structure: Xrms = Xp/√2 for both V and I.

dc_equivalence.name: DC Equivalence of RMS
dc_equivalence.formula: AC at Vrms = DC at same V for power
dc_equivalence.correct: An AC supply at Vrms delivers the same average power to a resistive load as a DC supply at voltage Vrms.

same as peak voltage DC.error: Peak would deliver more power than the AC.
same as peak voltage DC.fix: RMS gives equivalent power, not peak. Vrms < Vp.
same as peak voltage DC.action: 230 V RMS AC equals 230 V DC for power, not 325 V DC.

same as average voltage DC.error: Average AC voltage is zero over a full cycle.
same as average voltage DC.fix: RMS, not average, gives the DC equivalent for power.
same as average voltage DC.action: Average of sine wave = 0. RMS of sine wave = Vp/√2 ≠ 0.

twice the DC voltage.error: No factor of 2 in the equivalence.
twice the DC voltage.fix: AC at Vrms = DC at Vrms for power in resistive loads.
twice the DC voltage.action: 12 V RMS AC delivers same power as 12 V DC to a resistor.

persistent.gap: You do not understand why RMS gives DC equivalence.
persistent.action: Calculate P = V²/R for AC using Vrms and compare to DC. They should match.

why_rms_for_power.name: Why RMS for Power
why_rms_for_power.formula: P = V²/R, so squared values matter
why_rms_for_power.correct: Power depends on V², so the mean of V² (before taking root) determines average power. This is why RMS works for power calculations.

power depends on V, not V².error: Power formulas involve V²: P = V²/R.
power depends on V, not V².fix: P = VI = V²/R = I²R. The V² relationship is why RMS (root of mean of SQUARES) works.
power depends on V, not V².action: Write out P = V²/R. The squared voltage is key.

average voltage gives average power.error: Average V for AC is zero, but average power is not zero.
average voltage gives average power.fix: We need mean of V², not mean of V, because P ∝ V².
average voltage gives average power.action: Average of sin(t) = 0, but average of sin²(t) = 0.5.

peak voltage determines power.error: Peak is only reached momentarily, not continuously.
peak voltage determines power.fix: Average power comes from the average of V², which gives Vrms².

persistent.gap: You do not connect the RMS calculation to the power formula.
persistent.action: Derive: Pave = mean(V²)/R = Vrms²/R. The squaring in RMS matches power.

mains_voltage_values.name: Mains Voltage Values
mains_voltage_values.correct: Australian mains is 230 V RMS at 50 Hz, with a peak voltage of 230 × √2 ≈ 325 V.

230 V peak.error: 230 V is the RMS value, not the peak.
230 V peak.fix: Mains voltage is quoted as RMS. Peak = 230 × √2 ≈ 325 V.
230 V peak.action: When you see mains labelled 230 V, assume RMS unless stated otherwise.

230 V peak-to-peak.error: Vp-p for mains is about 650 V, not 230 V.

325 V RMS.error: 325 V is the peak, not the RMS.
325 V RMS.fix: Vrms = 230 V, Vp = 325 V. Do not confuse them.
325 V RMS.action: Mains quoted as 230 V means 230 V RMS.

persistent.gap: You do not know standard mains voltage values.
persistent.action: Memorise: Australian mains = 230 V RMS = 325 V peak = 650 V peak-to-peak.

rms_always_less_than_peak.name: RMS Always Less Than Peak
rms_always_less_than_peak.correct: For sinusoidal AC, RMS is always less than peak because Vrms = Vp/√2 ≈ 0.707 × Vp.

RMS is greater than peak.error: Impossible for sinusoidal signals. RMS < Vp always.

RMS equals peak.fix: Vrms = Vp/√2 ≠ Vp. For mains: 230 V ≠ 325 V.
RMS equals peak.action: If they were equal, the √2 factor would be pointless.

RMS can be greater or less.error: For sine waves, RMS is always less. No exceptions.
RMS can be greater or less.fix: The mathematics guarantees Vrms < Vp for sinusoidal AC.
RMS can be greater or less.action: This is a fixed relationship. Always check: is Vrms about 71% of Vp?

persistent.gap: You do not have intuition for the RMS-peak relationship.
persistent.action: Calculate Vrms/Vp for several examples. It should always be 0.707.

power_in_resistive_load.name: Power in Resistive Load
power_in_resistive_load.correct: Average power in a resistive load equals Vrms × Irms, which can also be written as Vrms²/R or Irms²R.

P = Vp × Ip.error: That gives peak power, not average power.
P = Vp × Ip.fix: Average power uses RMS values: P = Vrms × Irms = Vp × Ip / 2.

P = Vp²/R.error: Vp² gives peak power, not average.
P = Vp²/R.action: Use RMS values for average power calculations.

P = Vp-p × Ip-p.error: Peak-to-peak values do not give meaningful power.
P = Vp-p × Ip-p.action: Vp-p and Ip-p describe voltage swing, not power delivery.

persistent.gap: You do not know which values to use for power calculations.
persistent.action: Rule: average power always uses RMS values in resistive circuits.

ac_characteristics.instructions: Demonstrate mastery of AC voltage characteristics and common misconceptions.
